John Arrowwood wrote:

>But for most forms of simplification, simply reducing weights is 
>functionally equivalent, is it not?  If you have a fixed number of inputs, 
>some of which are not relevant, then learning a weight of 0 is equivalent to 
>simplifying them out of the genome, right?
>
>  
>
yes. Although the zero weights would contribute to a network complexity 
measurement, thus muddying up any experimentation! That problem can be 
addressed by factoring network complexity (genome length) into the 
fitness calculation. Someone tell me if I seem like a dog with a bone on 
this one? :)

Anyway this made made me think of another question: Disabled genes are 
mention in the original NEAT paper (enable bit). Are any of the current 
implementations utilizing this bit? Is it beneficial to implement 
dormant genes in NEAT?

Colin.
